body: While it is often said that politics abhors a vacuum, that adage has seldom had evidence as strong as the case of an upcoming City Council election in central Brooklyn. The incumbent, Councilwoman Yvette D. Clarke, was elected to Congress in November and will officially resign from the Council at the end of this month. And the list of people who
title: Open Council Seat in Brooklyn Becomes a Candidate Magnet

body: In decades past, the politicians who came out of central Brooklyn, New York's largest black community, were shaped by the civil rights struggles of the 1950s and '60s, with many coming of age politically during the Vietnam War era. But this year's elections, as well as last year's, represented a changing of the guard that could signal a wider shift
title: Changing of the Guard and Style For Politics of Central Brooklyn

body: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly inadvertently trumped their news conference. title: Chief's Command Comes at a Tough Time and Place

title: BASKETBALL; Officials at Two High Schools Say P.S.A.L. Ruling Is Too Harsh

body: Christmas at the Cratchits', 12 Years in the Future Readers of ''A Christmas Carol'' will remember that the purpose of the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come was to show Ebenezer Scrooge what would happen if he failed to mend his ways, not what would occur if he did. Now that future can be glimpsed in ''Tim and Scrooge,'' a lighthearted, often
title: Family Fare

body: In its aggressive strides to improve the quality of life, New York City has drastically curtailed its crime rate. It has overhauled its chaotic school system. But in one area, success is elusive: The city's rats remain as bold and showy as ever, darting through well-lighted subway stations as blasé New Yorkers watch and scurrying through its
title: In Epic Battle, the Rat Patrol Adjusts Its Aim and Digs In

body: An unidentified homeless man was found unconscious on a street corner in Crown Heights on Saturday night and later died from a stab wound, the police said yesterday. The man was found shortly before 7 p.m. at Nostrand Avenue and Park Place, the police said. Area residents said yesterday that he was a fixture in the neighborhood, and that he was
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Is Fatally Stabbed

body: Edward Monroe of East New York, Brooklyn, calls diabetes ''the sugar,'' a mild name for an insidious disease. It killed two of his cousins, a niece and, two years ago, his brother. His mother is in constant pain caused by diabetes. And now Mr. Monroe, who has had two operations to remove diabetes-related gangrene from his left foot, is afraid that
title: The Neediest Cases; Finding Help to Bear the Load as the Burdens of Diabetes Pile Up

body: A woman who leapt in front of a subway Monday, apparently out of remorse over smothering her son, said ''demons overtook her'' when she pressed a pillow to the boy's face and held it there until he became still, the police said yesterday. The woman, identified by relatives as Sadier Jean Noel, 27, said her son, Knil Jean Noel, 9, was despondent
title: Mother Who Leapt to Tracks Had Killed Son, Police Say

body: A woman jumped in front of a subway train in Brooklyn yesterday, just before her son was found dead in their Crown Heights apartment on his birthday, the police said. The boy was 9 years old. The woman, who jumped onto the tracks at Surf Avenue and West Eighth Street, in Coney Island, was taken to Lutheran Medical Center. She lost two fingers, the
title: Mother of Boy Found Dead Leaps to Tracks

body: The hunt for new ways of creating moderately priced housing in places with immoderate land prices has led housing experts in New York City to an unconventional thought: Why not tear down obsolete branch libraries and replace them with libraries that not only are bigger and better, but also have apartments built on top? In Brooklyn, a community
title: Stranger Than Fiction? Having People Live on Top of Branch Libraries

body: It was the first of three public hearings on the $4.2 billion Atlantic Yards development, and Umar Jordan, a 51-year-old resident of Bushwick, Brooklyn, strode to the front of the auditorium and offered a vigorous defense of the proposal. ''I'm here to speak for the underprivileged, the people that don't get the opportunity to work, the brothers
title: Perspectives on the Atlantic Yards Development Through the Prism of Race

body: THE faces staring out from the T-shirts printed in Ken Gordon's shop on Nostrand Avenue are uniformly young, black and smiling. But they also share something tragic. These are the faces of the dead, victims of the violence that, despite lowered crime rates citywide, remains stubbornly endemic in parts of central Brooklyn. ''It's a personal,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CENTRAL BROOKLYN; Shirts to Cry By

body: Joy Rolle, 30, of Brooklyn remembers when her contractions were coming stronger and closer together, before her water broke six years ago. It seemed like an eternity before she was wheeled into the delivery room. Her full-term pregnancy ended in an emergency Caesarean section because her son was in distress inside her womb. After recovery, she
title: The Neediest Cases; Help Meeting the Challenges of Parenthood and Poverty

body: To the Editor: In ''On the Block'' (Oct. 22), about the Atlantic Yards plan in Brooklyn, all the Fort Greene residents you interviewed were against it and all the Crown Heights residents were for it. It is easy to be in favor of a project that is more than a mile from your home, is a convenient destination for shoppers or basketball fans, and is
title: Atlantic Yards Plan: Be Afraid. Very Afraid.

body: AFTER 22 years in Dannemora, Sing Sing, Attica, Great Meadow, Elmira and the Downstate Correctional Facility at Fishkill, Alan Newton came home to the Bronx one unremarkable day last July, his age doubled, his life renewed. As had been proved incontrovertibly, he did not commit the crimes that made the prisons of New York State his home for more
title: Finally, a Life Resumed

body: NOT since the Dodgers departed in 1957 has there been a slugfest in Brooklyn like the one over Atlantic Yards. The plan is colossal -- 16 high-rise buildings and an 18,000-seat basketball arena on 22 acres near the borough's busy downtown -- and fans and opponents have matched its magnitude with their own statistics. The developer, Forest City
title: On the Block

title: HABITATS/Brooklyn; A Tropical Outpost In Crown Heights

body: Breakthrough in the Sky Q. My son, who's a helicopter buff, ran across a mention that the first helicopter rescue mission took place in New York Harbor during World War II. Is that true? A. Absolutely. To be accurate, the flight was a mercy mission, not a rescue, but it began a great tradition. On the morning of Jan. 3, 1944, a mysterious explosion
title: F. Y. I.

title: Family Fare

body: If there truly is a fine line between genius and madness, Gavin Dutchin crossed it often and with little warning. For the very mind that drove Mr. Dutchin's successes, making him his immigrant family's brightest hope and winning him degrees from elite schools, seemed to betray him unexpectedly, time and again. Mr. Dutchin, 38, is being treated in
title: Arrest in Pipe Attack on Officer Marks Undoing of Brilliant Mind

body: A black city councilwoman won the racially charged primary for a Congressional seat in central Brooklyn yesterday, beating back a challenge from a white councilman to win a seat created nearly four decades ago to increase minority representation in Congress. The councilwoman, Yvette D. Clarke, 41, narrowly beat three opponents to capture the seat,
title: THE NEW YORK PRIMARY: THE HOUSE; Councilwoman Wins Divisive House Primary

author: Sridhar Pappu is a correspondent for The Atlantic Monthly.
body: Matthew Haines is not concerned about furniture -- that is, to judge from his apartment on West 131st Street in Harlem. The décor might be described as Bachelor Minimal: a couple of chairs, a bed and a Mac on a desk in a back room. Two years ago, Haines, who at 36 is single, rail thin and typically unshaven, bought the apartment, a prewar
title: IF HOUSES COULD TALK

body: A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and charged with killing Damon Allen, a sanitation worker once called a hero, who tried to intervene during a dispute that ended in gunfire early on Monday morning, the police said. The police said that the suspect, Anthony Williams, 23, stole a man's wallet and bracelet on the street outside a residence in
title: Brooklyn Man, 23, Is Charged In Sanitation Worker's Death

body: A sanitation worker who caught a 4-year-old girl last year as she was thrown to safety from a burning building was shot in the head and killed early yesterday on a Brooklyn street, the police said. The man, Damon Allen, 33, was once again trying to help others, the police and witnesses said, urging them to take cover from the crossfire of a gun
title: Circumstances Made Him a Hero, and Then Cost Him His Life

body: A 26-year-old Brooklyn man was killed early yesterday by a spray of bullets that also wounded two teenagers who were bystanders, the police said. The man who died, Angel Durant, was shot several times at 12:26 a.m. in front of a deli at 137 Carlton Avenue in Fort Greene and was pronounced dead at Brooklyn Hospital Center an hour later, according to
title: Man Is Killed Outside Deli In Brooklyn

body: Democratic voters in the 19th Congressional District, which contains all of Putnam and parts of Orange, Rockland, Dutchess and Westchester counties, have the luxury of choosing from a roster of appealing candidates in their party's primary election on Sept. 12. title: A Congressional Primary

body: At a breakfast in Brooklyn yesterday morning, more than 50 ministers hailed City Councilwoman Yvette D. Clarke as the next member of Congress from their borough. title: Each Candidate Claims the Advantage in a Fierce 4-Way Congressional Race in Brooklyn

body: A track fire sent smoke billowing through a subway tunnel in Downtown Brooklyn during the evening rush yesterday, halting two subway trains carrying nearly 4,000 passengers, who had to be led to safety on the Manhattan Bridge. At least 25 people received minor injuries, including 10 passengers and three firefighters who were treated at hospitals
title: Smoky Track Fire Strands Riders On 2 Trains on Manhattan Bridge

body: A 51-year-old man was charged yesterday in the killing of a retired seamstress in her Crown Heights apartment on Saturday night, the police said. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Charged With Killing Woman, 69

title: Police Find Woman, 69, Strangled In Brooklyn

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Arrests In Post Office Robbery

Mr. Rogers, who lived in Brooklyn, was pronounced dead at
title: Shootings Kill 2 in Queens And Brooklyn

title: Martin Gallent, 75, a Champion of Open Spaces in a Crowded City

title: Spitzer and Dinkins Back Andrews in Campaign for a Brooklyn Congressional Seat

body: For the last four decades, the predominantly black population of central Brooklyn has been represented in Washington by one of its own, a tradition that dates to the 1968 victory of Shirley Chisholm, the first black woman elected to Congress. But now, in a district whose boundaries were drawn to strengthen black voting power, residents are locked
title: In Shirley Chisholm's Brooklyn, Rancor Over White Candidacy

body: THE dead-end signs in Arverne still stand, looming over streets that no longer exist in this Rockaways hamlet. Many of these roads, leading to the boardwalk and the ocean, have been fenced off. Others were long ago conquered by weeds and tall grass. But some of the roads have vanished for a reason that, as recently as a year or two ago, might have
title: STREET LEVEL/Arverne; Waiting for High Tide

body: The police yesterday identified a body that was found in a garbage bag on Thursday morning as that of a 16-year-old Brooklyn girl who was reported missing on Monday. The body of the teenager, Chanel Petro-Nixon, was discovered on the sidewalk outside a building at 212 Kingston Avenue in the Crown Heights neighborhood by the building's landlady, the
title: Body Identified as Missing Brooklyn Girl, 16

body: The Rev. Al Sharpton got involved yesterday in a racially charged congressional contest in Brooklyn, asking Senator Charles E. Schumer, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton to take a position in a primary where a white candidate is running for a seat historically held by blacks. The race involves the seat now held by
title: Sharpton Enters Fray Over House Seat

body: Some of Brooklyn's most prominent black officials said yesterday that they wanted to enlist party leaders at the national level to prevent a white politician from winning a Congressional seat long held by black politicians. In a news conference after a meeting of about two dozen black elected officials and civic leaders, including United States
title: Race Question Dominates House Seat Fight

body: A group of black and Hispanic elected officials from Brooklyn are scheduled to meet this morning to devise strategies to keep a white candidate from winning a Congressional seat of historical significance in black politics. It is not the first such meeting of these officials, nor is it likely to be the last. That there are talks so steeped in
title: Black Leaders Fear the Loss Of a House Seat

body: For years, Orthodox communities in New York and elsewhere have worked to revive the Jewish ritual of bathing in small pools known as mikvahs, building ever more elegant and comfortable versions to attract patrons accustomed to the gleaming Jacuzzis of spas, clubs and resorts. Usually taken by married women after their menstrual cycle or by women
title: Rabbis Say Private Ritual Baths Like One in Explosion Are Rare

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Mother Shot After Intervening In Fight

body: A 24-year-old man was fatally shot in Crown Heights last evening, the police said. Witnesses told the police that as the man stood in front of 225 Buffalo Avenue at 6:45 p.m., a gray Jeep approached and someone inside shot him. The vehicle then sped southward. The victim, whose name was not immediately released by the police, was taken to Kings
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Shot To Death

body: You can gauge the sweeping renovations to Kings County Hospital Center, the red-brick behemoth looming over central Brooklyn since it opened as an almshouse in 1831, by comparing the first and the most recent visits of Ronald William Reid, a 68-year-old former bank clerk and bus driver living in Bedford-Stuyvesant. He entered the world there on
title: A Transformation at a Brooklyn Hospital, From Gadgets to Ceiling-High Windows

body: A man died early yesterday after being shot near his home in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, the police said. Marlon Bagot, 21, managed to ring the doorbell to his home at 28 Hampton Place before he collapsed about 11:30 p.m. on Sunday, the police said. A relative who answered the door called 911, but Mr. Bagot, who had been hit twice in the torso, died
title: Brooklyn Man Fatally Shot

body: ABOUT 10 years ago, a field biologist with the American Museum of Natural History named Cal Snyder happened upon a grove of oak trees near Literary Walk in Central Park, a living but largely overlooked memorial to 590 soldiers of the 307th Infantry who lost their lives on the Western Front in World War I. The memory stayed with him, powerfully. ''I
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: READING NEW YORK; Memento Mori, an Eccentric Newsman and 'Dead Zoos'

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he had reservations about pursuing charges against an 8-year-old Brooklyn boy who the police say released the emergency brake on a parked school bus, which then fatally crushed a young girl. ''This is an 8-year-old child -- I don't know what facing charges means,'' Mr. Bloomberg told reporters at a
title: Bloomberg Says He Has Qualms About Charging an 8-Year-Old

body: An 8-year-old boy who climbed into a parked school bus, released the emergency brake and sent 26,000 pounds of steel rolling through Crown Heights, Brooklyn, on Monday was charged yesterday with criminally negligent homicide in the death of Amber Sadiq, 8, who was crushed between the bus's right undercarriage and a street pole. The boy, Tafari
title: Charge of Negligent Homicide For Boy, 8, in School Bus Death

body: An 8-year-old Brooklyn girl was killed yesterday afternoon after she was pinned on the sidewalk underneath a runaway school bus in Crown Heights, the police said. The bus had been left empty and legally parked by the driver while he went to lunch, the police said. An 8-year-old neighborhood boy, who witnesses said had entered the empty bus with a
title: Girl, 8, Killed in Brooklyn By a Runaway School Bus

body: BEYOND BLACK, by Hilary Mantel. (Picador, $14.) This darkly comic novel explores spiritualism through the story of a woman coming to terms with her disturbing past. Mantel's fat, middle-aged English heroine, Alison Hart, is a professional medium and clairvoyant -- a ''sensitive'' -- who depends on the help of a grizzled ''spirit guide'' named
title: Paperback Row

body: MARK AND ELIZABETH EHRHARDT and their two children see bright stars in the night sky when they look out their windows deep in Red Hook, Brooklyn. ''When was the last time you did that in this city?'' Mrs. Ehrhardt said on a recent morning, standing in her loftlike living room, her strawberry blond hair bubbling off her head. ''Everywhere else,
title: HABITATS/Red Hook, Brooklyn; An Unlikely Paradise, Right Around the Corner

body: ''Giuliani Time,'' Kevin Keating's new documentary about the former mayor of New York City, begins several years after its subject has left office, at the 2004 Republican National Convention. In his speech there, Rudolph W. Giuliani evoked the Sept. 11 attacks, and recalled that on that dreadful morning he had turned to Bernard B. Kerik, his police
title: FILM REVIEW; Confronting the Legacy of Giuliani: Crime, Race and Urban Politics

body: Attractions Museums and Sites HISTORIC RICHMOND TOWN, Staten Island Historical Society, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmond Town. More than 25 buildings, from the late 17th to the 19th centuries, restored and furnished. title: SPARE TIMES

body: A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday in connection with the fatal shooting of his uncle at the apartment they shared in Crown Heights, the police said. The man, Orangel S. Hill, 27, shot his uncle, David Husband, 69, six times shortly after midnight at their apartment on President Street, the police charged. A pistol was recovered, and Mr. Hill
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Charged In Uncle's Shooting

body: A man was fatally shot just after midnight in Crown Heights yesterday, the police said. Witnesses and the police said the man, whom the police did not identify pending notification of his relatives, was shot three times in the chest about 12:40 a.m. while fleeing one or more assailants on President Street. Caroline Lendore, 39, said the shooting
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Fatally Shot

body: Attractions Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. Through Aug. 20, ''Darwin,'' an exhibition devoted to the naturalist, which includes fossils and live creatures as well as a reconstruction of Darwin's study at Down House. Through June 23, ''The Butterfly Conservatory: Tropical Butterflies Alive in
title: Spare Times

body: Joseph J. Esposito enjoys, among the rank and file of the New York Police Department, a reputation as a ''cop's cop,'' as much a product of the department as any school or neighborhood, joining at age 18 in the bygone days of officer trainees. In the almost 38 years since he became a trainee, he has risen to be the highest-ranking member of the
title: Colleagues of Police Chief Cite His Bond With Jews

body: A hipster synagogue grows in SoHo, drawing large crowds with its ''Torah cocktail parties'' in fancy loft apartments and user-friendly prayer services designed especially for the uninitiated. A group of New York-area congregations, along with others across the country, refashion their synagogues into religious multiplexes on the Sabbath, featuring
title: With Yoga, Comedy and Parties, Synagogues Entice Newcomers

body: Yesterday morning, Shirley Leftridge jogged briskly down the middle of a Brooklyn street, running away from the places where, her neighbors said, the men in her immediate family had been killed. In the late 1980's, they said, Ms. Leftridge's husband died violently somewhere near her Crown Heights home, in circumstances the neighbors could not
title: For Family in Brooklyn, a Third Violent Death

body: When a group of business owners, community activists and musicians formed the Central Brooklyn Jazz Consortium in 1999, their goal was to preserve a jazz culture deemed to be withering at the grassroots level. The following year, they applied that sense of purpose to the first annual Central Brooklyn Jazz Festival, along with an educational
title: JAZZ FESTIVAL REVIEW; Spiritual Sax Man for a Spiritual Job

body: Hundreds of people attended pro- or anti-immigration rallies in the New York area yesterday, the latest in a nationwide series of demonstrations held as Congress debates legislation that would substantially revamp the country's immigration laws. The rallies, held in Manhattan and Queens, and in Bogota, N.J., were mostly modest affairs. The largest
title: Immigration Debates Mirror Concerns in Washington

body: To the Editor: I take issue with your description of the Crown Heights case (''From Jail Cell, a Convict Challenges a Prosecutor,'' news article, March 16). After a Kings County jury acquitted Lemrick Nelson Jr. of killing Yankel Rosenbaum, I, along with Senator Charles E. Schumer, met with Attorney General Janet Reno to implore her to open a civil
title: Crown Heights Case

author: Jeff Byles is the author of ''Rubble: Unearthing the History of Demolition.''
body: ON May 22, 1936, the photographer Berenice Abbott ambled along the Brooklyn waterfront, thrilling to river-wrapped vistas and old warehouses that glowered with imposing grandeur. Crossing the narrow streets on one of her celebrated sorties to shoot the surging metropolis for the federal Works Progress Administration, she turned her lens upon a
title: Amid the Facades, Furrowed Brows

body: Funny how a piece of furniture can bring strangers together. Beau Willimon and his girlfriend were looking for a table for their apartment in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. On the Web site Craigslist, they saw an elegant oval dining table with a rich mahogany finish: $65. Mr. Willimon called the number. The man at the other end, a Mr. Klein (he never
title: A $65 Table, and a Tale to Tell Around It

body: A decade ago, the paths of a prosecutor and a young drug abuser crossed in a murder conviction. It was an ordinary verdict at an extraordinary time, a redeeming victory for the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes. The prosecutor, Michael F. Vecchione, who traveled to Puerto Rico with an assistant to meet a witness in the case, built a
title: From Jail Cell, a Convict Challenges a Prosecutor

body: The Police Department is looking for the driver of a white Chevrolet van that was seen in Crown Heights around the time a man was shot dead there while parking his car. The van was seen on a security videotape heading south on Schenectady Avenue, a block south of where the man, Frederick Klein, 47, was shot at 1:30 a.m. on Tuesday on Carroll
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Police Seek Van's Driver

body: Firefighters rescued a woman from the top floor of a burning 24-story building early yesterday morning, the Fire Department said. The woman climbed onto a window ledge at 1700 Bedford Avenue in Crown Heights about 3 a.m. to escape smoke, which had filled the building. A firefighter was lowered by a rope and carried the woman to safety, according to
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Rescue From Burning Building

body: A man apparently looking for a parking spot near his home in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, early yesterday died after he was shot through the window of his van, causing him to lose control and sideswipe several parked cars before he crashed and the van caught fire the police said. The man, Frederick Klein, 47, was killed after a bullet pierced the van's
title: Man Fatally Shot While Driving Van

body: Laboratory tests have found no traces of anthrax in an apartment in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, where a man worked on unprocessed animal hides obtained from Vado Diomande, the New York City man who contracted inhalation anthrax this month. The city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, which released the test results yesterday, said it had told
title: An Apartment in Brooklyn Is Cleared in Anthrax Test

body: For two agonizing days, as Kassoum Fofana lay critically injured in a hospital bed after a fire that destroyed his home, relatives and friends struggled with the most painful of tasks: how to tell him that his wife and two of his children had died in the blaze that he managed to escape. The fire, at 1033 Pacific Street in Crown Heights, Brooklyn,
title: For Fire Victim, a Clergyman Is Chosen to Bring Tragic News

body: The New York City man who contracted inhalation anthrax after working with untreated animal hides remained in serious condition yesterday, as the authorities awaited results of laboratory tests from the Crown Heights, Brooklyn, home of one of the man's colleagues. The man, Vado Diomande, a 44-year-old drummer and dancer, is believed to have inhaled
title: City Officials Await Anthrax Tests Results

body: The Greenwich Village home of a man infected with inhalation anthrax after working with unprocessed animal skins tested positive for the deadly germ, city officials said yesterday. Tests on the van and workplace used by the man, Vado Diomande, also tested positive for traces of anthrax. At the same time, Mr. Diomande's health worsened. Officials at
title: Anthrax Traces Found at 3 Sites as Victim Worsens

body: The authorities widened their investigation into possible anthrax contamination yesterday to include an apartment in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, and medical officials were giving antibiotics to seven people who could have been exposed to the spores. An eight-member team from the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, including two
title: A NEW CASE OF ANTHRAX: OVERVIEW; A Wider Inquiry, as More People Get Antibiotics and 2nd Apartment Is to Be Checked

body: IT'S 10 p.m. and the wedding is in full swing in a ground-floor apartment in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. The groom, wearing a crisp white dress, is writhing belly-down on the floor and hissing fiercely. Soon he is going to look into his bride's eyes and pledge his everlasting love to her. But instead of the clink of champagne glasses, she cracks a
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: THE CHASE; A Marriage, When the Spirit Moves Them

body: Attractions Museums MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, 1120 Fifth Avenue, at 103rd Street. Tomorrow at 3 p.m., a sword dance performance in celebration of the 21st New York Sword Dance Festival. Sunday at 2 p.m., a screening of ''The Cameraman'' (1928), the silent film directed by Edward Sedgwick and starring Buster Keaton, with live piano
title: Spare Times

body: Rabbi Yehuda Chitrik, a legendary storyteller in the Lubavitcher community, died on Tuesday at Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 106 and lived in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, the hub of the worldwide Lubavitcher Hasidic movement. The death was announced by Rabbi Zalman Shmotkin of the Chabad Lubavitch Media Center in Brooklyn. One of Rabbi
title: Rabbi Yehuda Chitrik, 106, a Legend in Lubavitcher Circles

author: E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com
body: AS identical twins, Uché and Oni Blackstock were always together. They lived together, studied together, earned their M.D. degrees together. When they were little, all that togetherness was cute. But at age 28, it wasn't cute anymore. It was verging on pathological. ''We were so much in each other's space,'' Uché said. They found themselves
title: THE HUNT; After a Life Together, Living Apart

body: As the pay and purchasing power of Manhattan residents have moved higher and higher, incomes in all four of the boroughs outside Manhattan have trailed inflation over the last few years, in a stark example of the increasing income disparity in New York City. In terms of wages, Manhattan families are doing better on average than those in the rest of
title: Wage Squeeze Hits All of City But Manhattan

body: Joan Maynard, who shepherded the preservation of the remnants of Weeksville, a once-thriving 19th-century community of free blacks in Brooklyn that had faded from maps and memory, died on Sunday at her home in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. She was 77. Her death was confirmed by Pamela Green, her successor as executive director of the Society for the
title: Joan Maynard Dies at 77; Preserved a Black Settlement

body: Gov. George E. Pataki's proposal to give some parents a $500 tax credit that could be used to pay for private or parochial school tuition is drawing some unexpected support in the Democratic-led State Assembly. The backing is coming from some legislators from New York City who say that they are tired of waiting for Mr. Pataki to increase aid to
title: Governor's Tax-Credit Plan Finds Unexpected Support

body: Each week, about 25,000 customers find their way by car, foot or public transportation to a five-month-old Home Depot store at 585 DeKalb Avenue, which sits on a five-acre site next to Public School 54, in a residential section of Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. ''It's excitement all day long,'' said Ricky Campbell, the manager of the store, which
title: SQUARE FEET; Bringing a Big-Box Store to a Tough Area of Brooklyn

body: BENEZRA--Meyer. A brilliant legal and curious mind died December 29, 2005. Devoted son, father and friend, the Brooklyn College and Columbia Law graduate practiced law in NYC for nearly 60 years, most recently at Weisman Celler Spett & Modlin. Steadfast advisor to the Yeshivah of Crown Heights (CHY) and valued member of its Board of Trustees, he
title: Paid Notice: Deaths BENEZRA, MEYER.
